ANNUAL ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR PUBLIC
SERVICES AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES FOR 1960


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

[Mr SPEAKER in the Chair]



2.35 p.m.

    The Chairman: Will the Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before the Committee proceeds with the consideration of the Main Estimates and the Development Estimates?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I so signify.

    The Chairman: Turning to the main estimates. For the convenience of hon. Members, I intend taking the total for each head as it appears in the last column of the abstract of estimated expenditure on page 31 of Paper Cmd. (New Series) 32 of 1959.

    The attention of hon. Members is drawn to Heads 1 and 5. In regard to Head 1, Yang di-Pertuan Negara, the total in the last column - Amount to be voted 1960 - should be amended to read `$273,660'. This is because of an addition of the sum of $42,860 which appears as item (1) of subhead 1 at page 35. The note on that page numbered (ii) reads:

    "Sum charged on the Consolidated Fund. Monthly Salary not yet fixed."

    In fact, the sum has not as yet been charged on the Consolidated Fund and therefore it is required to be voted upon for 1960.

    In regard to Head 5, Public Service Commission, the total in the last column at page 31 should be amended to read `$131,350.' This is because of an addition of the sum of $10 which appears at page 49 as item (4) of subhead 1.

    The note against that item numbered (i) also reads:

    "Sums charged on the Consolidated Fund."

Column: 905



    In fact, the sum of $10 in item (4) has not as yet been so charged and therefore that sum is required to be voted upon for 1960.

    These alterations mean that the final total in the last column of page 31 should now read '$246,646,260'.

    Dealing now with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper.

Column: 905

MAIN ESTIMATES, 1960



    Head 1 -

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of sub-head 1.

    Mr Speaker, the main reason for my wishing to move this amendment has, in fact, been cleared to some extent by you, Sir. Am I to understand that it is this meeting that has been called upon to fix the personal emoluments of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara? I should have thought that this would have been done very much earlier rather than left to this last moment. Perhaps another point on which an explanation might be given, Mr Speaker, Sir, is the increase of $10 on the previous 1959 estimates in the total sum payable to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. The third point on which an explanation might be given is whether on the total amount payable to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, income tax would be paid?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): I would have preferred, Mr Speaker, Sir, to have been able to determine the emoluments of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before today. Members are aware that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara took office on the 3rd of December. We were all pre-occupied with Loyalty Week and there was this other consideration, that the emolument to be fixed was dependent upon the manner in which he shall live after he was installed in office.

    He has, from the evening of the 2nd of December, moved into the domain which we now call Istana Negara, but he has expressed to me his desire not to reside in the Istana itself. He has informed me that he would prefer his

Column: 906

private capacity to be distinct from his official capacity. He has therefore chosen to live in a bungalow inside the domain which used to be occupied by the former Under-Secretaries. He will, however, discharge the functions of his office - both the ceremonial and the official functions - from Government House. Istana Negara will be his official place for State business. This has to be borne in mind when we decide on the emoluments to be given him, because whilst Istana Negara is maintained completely out of State funds, his family and household commitments in the bungalow inside the domain will be on his own personal account. Bearing in mind that the former Governor received £5,000 as his salary, and £1,500 as his duty allowance, we decided that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara shall receive the sum shown as the estimated expenditure in 1960, namely $42,860. Another reason is this: that the order of precedence, which has now been settled by the Negara in consultation with Her Majesty the Queen, establishes the "Negara" as first in the order of precedence; myself as the Prime Minister second; third the Chief Justice; and fourth the Speaker. As you know, Mr Speaker, Sir, your emoluments have been determined by the Constitution until June 1960, and I sincerely hope that this House will have equally charitable and generous considerations in mind when June 1960 comes. I am in receipt of $50 more than you, Mr Speaker, Sir, and although we originally intended to fix the Negara's emoluments at $3,500, which will make it slightly less than £5,000 we decided that there was no real reason why our Yang di-Pertuan Negara, in view of the fact that he would have to maintain his own family and his own private bungalow, should get less than £5,000.

    The second point. There is really no mystery about the increase of $10. If the Member for Farrer Park will look at the item, he will find, under the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, Governor - $42,850, and then the Yang di-Pertuan Negara/ United Kingdom Commissioner $10. The Treasury procedure of budgeting requires a token $10. It was, in fact, $42,860, because the United Kingdom

Column: 907

Commissioner was at the same time the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. The United Kingdom Government has, from the coming into force of the Constitution, paid half the emoluments, duty allowance and entertainment allowance of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. Therefore, the Treasury brought $60 down to $50, put $10 token against the other item - Yang di-Pertuan Negara/United Kingdom Commissioner.

    Finally, the question of income tax. We have, after the Yang di-Pertuan Negara indicated to us that he would prefer to live in a private bungalow inside the domain instead of the Istana Negara proper itself, decided that he shall be exempt from income tax.

2.45 p.m.

    The Chairman: It is so provided in the law, is it not?

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, there was a certain amount of argument as to whether or not it is so provided in the law. The intention of those who went to the London Conference is supposed to have been embodied in the law. If I remember correctly, it was our original intention that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, unlike the Governor in the past, should not be above the law. Unfortunately, it has been so drafted that there may be a measure of doubt. In any case, we have now decided, because of the considerations that I have stated, that he will be exempt from income tax.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, in view of the explanation of the Prime Minister, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I put in this amendment for the purpose of eliciting information from the Prime Minister. Sir, under the previous constitution and under Colonial constitutions, this allowance of $1,800 has been inserted from time immemorial. This is to allow payment to a civil servant who, during the absence of the Governor from Singapore,

Column: 908

was doing the job of Officer Administering the Government.

    Sir, in the case of Yang di-Pertuan Negara, it is not improbable that he too may have to be away from Singapore in the discharge of his duties. But I do not think that it will be proper-and I am sure it is not the intention of the Government-that the Deputy Yang di-Pertuan Negara should be drawn from the Civil Service, or from anywhere else, or even that the British Commissioner be allowed to be the Acting or the Deputy Yang di-Pertuan Negara. Surely, when a special Deputy Yang di-Pertuan Negara has to be appointed during the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's absence, that allowance of $1,800 is not enough.

    Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head I be reduced by $10 in respect of item (16) of sub-head 1.

    The Prime Minister: On a subject which is well-known to you, Mr Speaker, Sir, we have determined that, in the event of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara being unable to act either through his being indisposed, or being away for short periods, a dormant commission will be issued which entitles you, Mr Speaker, to act as the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. Should, however, it interfere with a sitting of this Assembly, it is at your pleasure to opt out from these duties, in which case the Chief Justice would deputise for the Yang di-Pertuan Negara.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, whilst I would not belittle the arduous duties of your high office in this Assembly, I should think that, if you move up from number four in the order of precedence to number one, it surely entitles a token payment to be made to signify the august position to which you would move from time to time in the course of your duties. It has been worked out at about $40 odd per day of actual deputising. I am quite sure that, whilst the Opposition have shown an inclination to be more generous than we are, you will certainly bear with us if we say that, in view of the frugal and thrifty habits of this Government, it is not an expression of disrespect to you.

Column: 909



    The Chairman: Free from income tax?

    The Prime Minister: Unlike the question of the emoluments of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara - I do not think there is any doubt about it in the Constitution itself - it is subject to tax; but if a case can be made out, I am quite sure the Minister for Finance will give it his careful and due consideration!

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the light of the explanation given, may I ask for leave to withdraw the amendment?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $273,660 for Head 1 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 909



    Head 2 -

    The following amendment stood in the name of Tun Lim Yew Hock:-

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 2 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (30) of sub-head 1.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, since it is on the same subject, I am leaving it to my colleague, the Member for Farrer Park.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 2 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (30) of sub-head 1.

    Sub-head 1 (30) says "District Judges and Magistrates, twelve". Could I ask the Minister for Law: How many of these posts are now held by officers? How many of the holders have more than three years' experience? How many of them have less than three years' experience?

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the questions from the Member for Farrer Park, I would like to point out that there are three District Judges and nine Magistrates. What was the next question?

    Mr Rajah: How many years' experience?

    Mr Byrne: In the case of the Acting District Judge and First Magistrate, Mr Eu Cheow Chye, he qualified as a barrister in 1951. In the case of Mr Choor

Column: 910

Singh, he passed the Bar final in 1950, and was called to the Bar in 1955. In the case of Mr K. T. Alexander, a District Judge also, he qualified as a legal officer in Madras in 1932, and as a barrister in 1952. In the case of Mr Charlie Foo Chee Hee Tung, a Magistrate, he was called to the Bar in 1953. In the case of Mr Coomaraswamy, he was called to the Bar in 1956. In the case of Mr Goh Heng Leong, he was called to the Bar in 1957. In the case of Mr Lim Ewe Huat, he was called to the Bar in 1956. In the case of Mr Teo Chan Hong, he was called to the Bar in 1958. Mr T. Ariarajah was called to the Bar in 1958, and Mr Noel A. De Rozario in 1957.

    As to experience, Mr Speaker, Sir, you will see that, except for Mr Eu Cheow Chye, Mr Choor Singh, Mr K. T. Alexander and Mr Charlie Foo, the rest of them, I think, have less than three years' experience.

    Mr Rajah: I would like to withdraw that amendment, Sir, with the permission of the House.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 2 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 1.

Mr Speaker, Sir, I have framed the amendment in this way in order that I may be permitted to speak on the Rent Conciliation Board, not so much particularly on items (67), (68), (69) and (70) as they appear therein, but on the question of the President of the Rent Conciliation Board and the principle appertaining to such appointments.

    Under the Rent Control Ordinance, Mr Speaker, the provision is that the President of the Rent Conciliation Board should be a person who could be appointed to be a District Judge under the Courts Ordinance. He should have that amount of experience which would enable him to be appointed a District Court Judge. The practice appertaining to appointment to the post of President, Rent Conciliation Board, has always been to appoint either a District Judge, or somebody who was not a practising member of the Bar. Could the House be

Column: 911

informed whether the present President of the Rent Conciliation Board is a practising member of the Bar?

    The Chairman: The Question is, "That the sum to be allocated for Head 2 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 1", and, as indicated, the debate is confined to the Rent Conciliation Board.

3.00 p.m.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Ong Eng Guan): Mr Speaker, section 8 of the Rent Control Ordinance provides for the composition of the Board. Section 8 (3) says:

    "The President shall possess the qualifications required for a District Judge under the provisions of section 56 of the Courts Ordinance, and shall preside at all sessions of the Board." Mr Speaker, when the new Government came in, we made a careful analysis of the old Rent Conciliation Board and we found that it was mainly a Board operated in the interest of the property and landlord class. We found that of the 15 members of the Board, 10 represented The property class, three represented the Singapore Clerical Union and two represented the T.U.C. So we have taken steps to rectify the position in order that the population of Singapore can be better represented on the Board.

    As I have said just now, under the Rent Control Ordinance, it has been laid down that the President shall possess the qualifications required for a District Judge. It does not state that the President should be a District Judge. Mr Speaker, we have checked up with the new President, and he possesses the qualifications required for a District Judge.

    Mr Speaker, the second point which the Member for Farrer Park has raised is that the President should not be a practising lawyer. It is not laid down anywhere in the Ordinance. If it happens that the past President was a District Judge, that is because one had been appointed. There is nothing in the Ordinance to say that the President of the Rent Conciliation Board should not be a practising lawyer.

Column: 912



    Mr Rajah: As far as I understand the Minister's reply, though he did not specifically say so, it would appear, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the present President of the Rent Conciliation Board is, in fact, a practising member of the Bar. If that is accepted, then I will proceed on that basis. I would suggest to the Minister that it is highly undesirable for a practising member of the Bar to be appointed to such a post. In his normal practice, he would come into contact with all sorts of people - tenants, landlords and owners of property. I do not say that he will be influenced by them - but a number of people, who might not otherwise have gone to him on matters other than those appertaining to the Rent Conciliation Board, might go to him and seek his services merely for the reason that when their matters come up before him for consideration as President, they might get an added advantage. Surely, Sir, the Rent Conciliation Board is a court of law. All its proceedings are judicial proceedings. This is the thin end of the wedge. Is the Government going to allow a practising member of the Bar to become a District Judge? Is the Government going to allow a practising member of the Bar to become a High Court Judge? The President of the Rent Conciliation Board is a judicial officer because the proceedings of the Rent Conciliation Board by statute are judicial proceedings. If I am required to cite chapter and verse, I am prepared to do so, but by virtue of the Ordinance itself all proceedings of the Rent Conciliation Board are judicial proceedings. If the Government accept the principle that a practising member of the Bar could become the President of the Rent Conciliation Board, then I think they should also accept the principle that a High Court Judge could practise his profession at the same time.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, whilst I do not concede the validity of the argument put forward by the Member for Farrer Park, I will be the first to admit and to uphold the principle that he who adjudicates must be above criticism or suspicion. This appointment, Sir, was made by my colleague the Minister for National Development. He is not a lawyer and is therefore not well versed in

Column: 913

the principles of jurisprudence. Not because there is any validity in his argument but because of the general principle that the dispensation of justice - be it in a judicial or quasi-judicial tribunal - should be above criticism, I can assure the Member for Farrer Park that the position of the Rent Conciliation Board will be rectified.

    Mr Rajah: I thank the Prime Minister for his statement, and I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $1,598,730 for Head 2 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 913



    Head 4 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 4 be reduced by $100.

    Sir, this amendment is introduced by me with a view to ascertaining from the Government what their views are on the independence of the Legislature staff. It has been the practice elsewhere that the Department of the Legislature should be independent of the Executive and that the staff of the Legislature should hold loyalty to the Legislature itself and to each and every Member of the Assembly, irrespective of his Party affiliations.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is a hoary subject. We have had it on and off for the last four years. Just to demonstrate his flexibility and resilience, the former Chief Minister now comes forward as the protagonist of the independence of the staff of the Legislature.

    You will remember, Sir, that this was one of the matters which you strenuously pressed when the Constitutional talks were going on in London in 1956, again in 1957, and again in 1958. For three years running, we have debated this. We have gone over the arguments forwards and backwards umpteen times. In theory, if you go according to the principle of the separation of powers, the Legislature is independent of the Executive, and the Executive has no control over the Judiciary. The Executive implements the laws made by the Legislature. The Judiciary interprets them.

Column: 914

Then the logical conclusion one comes to is that the staff of the Legislature must be recruited separately and must be a separate establishment.

    All these arguments having been taken into consideration, we decided that the opportunities for advancement in such a small hierarchy in such a small establishment are so limited that this Assembly would find it extremely difficult to attract suitable recruits. For that reason, you, Mr Speaker, Sir, had put forward the rather ingenious suggestion that there should be an open service in the lower levels but that it should be a closed service in the higher levels. We have all seen the succession of Clerks of this Assembly since 1950. In 1950, my friend and colleague, now the Minister for Labour and Law, officiated in that capacity. And so it has been going on. The turnover has been fairly rapid. But we all hope that it has been stabilised by the present incumbent who, I hope, is sufficiently strong and healthy, and dedicated to the intricate and complicated art of Standing Orders.

    But, Mr Speaker, Sir, when you pressed this matter again on our assumption of office, we stated that we would rather allow a reasonable period of time to elapse before we review the decision which we took after being pressed on this issue three years running. There were cogent reasons why we did not accept your views then and why the former Chief Minister also did not accept your views when he was in a position to determine these matters. I should hate to admit that we made those decisions in haste and without due consideration - which we would, in fact, be doing if we altered our decision so soon after the implementation of the Constitution. After a decent and reasonable interval has elapsed in which we are all satisfied that your compromise proposal is feasible, workable and sound, we shall take necessary steps to implement it. But right at this moment, I give no assurance of any kind that the position will be altered.

    This is part of the past that we have inherited. There is also this other difficulty - that if we are to make it a closed service even on the top levels, the theory

Column: 915

of not depriving an officer of his expectation of further promotion must apply to the present incumbent, and therefore he should be given the option to opt out of the closed service.

    Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, you may find yourself with a new Clerk of the Assembly faster than you would otherwise have found yourself. Bearing all these considerations in mind, I think the position is that it be best left alone, and that it be considered after we all have had time to look into the practical merits of the proposal of a closed service for the top positions inside the Legislative establishment.

    The Chairman: This is one occasion when the Speaker regrets that he cannot debate!

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is the first time that we have heard that there have been discussions between you and the Prime Minister on this subject. In view of what he has said - that the matter is in his mind and that he will require a decent and reasonable interval before he can make up his mind as to whether or not the Legislature should be made independent of the Executive - I would ask leave to withdraw the amendment.

    

The Prime Minister rose -

    The Chairman: May I explain the procedure? The procedure is that if a Member gets up to speak after a request for leave to withdraw is made, then, of course, a vote must be taken.

    The Prime Minister: So be it, Mr Speaker. I would like to make this point. It is important that one should not move from pillar to post without being reminded which was the last pillar one hid behind.

    The last time the Chief Minister took his stand on the question of a separate establishment for the Legislature, he decided that the scope for promotion and the attraction to the service were so limited that he would not be able to recruit good enough staff into the Legislative establishment. Therefore, he decided

Column: 916

against a separate Legislative establishment. And we agreed with him. It is not just a question of our needing a decent interval before we make up our minds. We want a decent interval to elapse before we change our minds. As I have said, Sir, if we conceded to your compromise proposal, it is not because we change our minds but because you had made out a strong and convincing case for a separate service at the top level.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    The sum of $661,180 for Head 4 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

    The Chairman: I take it that the Minister for Finance will cast his eagle eye on these figures, because they seem to be so close to each other that I might make a mistake!

Column: 916



    Head 7 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 7 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (9) of sub-head 1.

    Sir, I tabled this amendment with a view to seeking information from the Prime Minister as to whether or not it was correct that when there was an Information Officer for Singapore in the United Kingdom, he was recalled on the grounds that no useful purpose could be served by having such an appointment in the United Kingdom. Perhaps the Press report on this was correct.

3.15 p.m.

    The Prime Minister: I am not aware, Mr Speaker, Sir, of the Press report referred to by the Member for Cairnhill, but I am quite prepared to state the facts in regard to this Information Officer, Mr Yeh.

    The former Chief Minister will recall that when the Federation of Malaya decided that they would be separately represented in London, their Information Officer who used to discharge duties for the Singapore Government was no longer able to discharge these functions. Therefore, as far back as 1957, it was

Column: 917

necessary, if we were to have an Information Officer in London, to make our own appointment.

    Sir, no such appointment was made until a few months before the general elections. My record shows that Mr Yeh, former Chinese Press Liaison Officer to the Chief Minister, took office in London three months before the general elections. After the general elections, and in view of the fact that the Minister for Culture, who is well advised in these matters, considered that it was not a judicious appointment, we decided to recall him. He was recalled. He returned on the 2nd September and was posted to the Ministry of Culture. On the 4th October, he tendered his resignation, obviously because he did not fit in with his duties in the Department or perhaps because he was not posted to a Department sufficiently important enough for him. Be that as it may, the post has been left in the Estimates because it is our intention that, when a suitable applicant has been found, an Information Officer will be sent to London.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I quite agree that it is important that there should be an Information Officer in the United Kingdom. But why I brought up this subject is because of the report of the P.A.P. in the Press but I was not going into the question of the present holder since he has resigned or of the previous holder of this post. I was just going to find out whether it was considered important enough by the Government that there should be such an Officer in the United Kingdom and the Prime Minister has said so. With that information, Sir, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 7 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (18) of sub-head 1.

    Sub-head 1 provides for four chauffeurs for the office of the Prime Minister. Mr Speaker, if you will be good enough to turn to Head 1, page 36 of the Estimates, item (14), you will find there the item "Chauffeurs, five". That is for the

Column: 918

Yang di-Pertuan Negara. May I ask the Prime Minister why he needs four chauffeurs when the Yang di-Pertuan Negara only needs five?

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, I do not require four chauffeurs. I have got on in the world quite peacefully and. I hope, in a safe and business-like manner without having had a chauffeur.
